Rev. Sam Peden |separations = |associations = [[Irish Council of Churches]], [[European Liberal Protestant Network]], [[International Association for Religious Freedom]]. |area = [[Ireland]], [[Northern Ireland]] |congregations = 33 |members = 4,000 | website = http://www.nspresbyterian.org/ |footnotes = }} The '''Non-subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland''' derives its name and its liberal and tolerant identity from early 18th century Presbyterian ministers who refused to subscribe at their ordination to the [[Westminster Confession]], a standard [[Reformed]] ([[Calvinist]]) statement of faith; and who formed, in 1725, the [[Presbytery (church polity)|Presbytery]] of [[County Antrim|Antrim]]. A similar phenomenon led to the creation of the [[Remonstrant]] Synod of Ulster in 1830. The two bodies created the Non-subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland (NSPCI) in 1910.<ref>''The EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica'' 1926 "In 1910 the Antrim Presbytery, Remonstrant Synod and Synod of Munster were united as the General Synod of the non-subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland. They have 38 congregations and some mission stations."</ref> The [[Synod of Munster]] became part of the NSPCI in 1935. Many Non-subscribing Presbyterians keep close contact with the [[General Assembly of Unitarian and Free Christian Churches|Unitarians]] and are sometimes identified as such, though they are distinct bodies. The Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland has associations with the [[IARF]] but not with the [[ICUU]].<ref>Erwin Fahlbusch ''The encyclopedia of Christianity'' v5 p605 - 2008 "Eventually the particular needs of the specific Unitarian and Universalist and Unitarian-Universalist IARF ... Thus, for example, the Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland has associations with the [[IARF]] but not with the [[ICUU]] ..."</ref> The IARF does not believe in the divinity of Jesus Christ: <blockquote>"Unitarians believe that Jesus was a man, unequivocally human. It has long been our view that to talk of him as God is unfaithful to his own understanding of himself."<ref>[http://www.unitarian.org.uk/intro/faq.shtml?9 Unitarian website, Retrieved 11 October 2012.]</ref></blockquote> Today, the denomination has thirty-one congregations in [[Northern Ireland]] and two congregations in the [[Republic of Ireland]], with a total of about four thousand members. They are served by fewer than twenty ministers; both women and men serve as ministers. The NSCPI is a member of the [[Irish Council of Churches]], the [[European Liberal Protestant Network]] and the [[International Association for Religious Freedom]]. ==References== {{reflist}} * ''A Short History of the Non- Subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland'' by John Campbell (Belfast, 1914). ==See also== *[[Free Christian]]ity *[[General Assembly of Unitarian and Free Christian Churches]] ===Other Presbyterian denominations in Ireland=== *[[Free Presbyterian Church of Ulster]] *[[Presbyterian Church of Ireland]] *[[Reformed Presbyterian Church of Ireland]] *[[Evangelical Presbyterian Church (Ireland)|Evangelical Presbyterian Church]] ==External links== *[http://www.nspresbyterian.org/ Non-subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland] {{DEFAULTSORT:Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Church Of Ireland}} [[Category:Nontrinitarian denominations in Ireland]] [[Category:Christianity in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Presbyterian denominations in Europe]] [[Category:Unitarianism]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1910]] [[Category:Presbyterian denominations and unions established in the 20th century]] [[Category:All-Ireland organisations]] [[Category:Nontrinitarian denominations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Presbyterianism in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Presbyterianism in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Protestantism in Ireland]] [[Category:Christianity in the Republic of Ireland by denomination]] [[Category:Religion in Ireland]] {{calvinism-stub}}
